text: The peptide contains two amino acids in the unusual amino acid, m-diaminopimelic acid, has an extra amine group, which forms an amide link to a cross-bridged peptide.
The cross-linked peptides of neighboring glycan strands form the cage of the sacculus.
The amide link forms with the fourth amino acid of end of the chain.
Nevertheless, a few prokaryotes, such as the mycoplasmas, have a cell membrane with no outer layers, depending on host fluids for osmotic balance.
The peptide extension can form crossbridges connecting parallel strands of glycan.
Many species possess additional coverings, such as an outer membrane or an S-layer.
Archaeal membranes have ether-linked terpenoids, which confer increased stability at high temperature and extreme acidity.
Some archaea with only a cell membrane grow in extreme acid (pH zero); how they survive is unknown.
lactate group of muramic acid forms an amide link with the amino terminus of a short peptide containing four to six amino acid residues.
structural support is the cell wall (see Fig.
Some archaea have diglycerol tetraethers, which form a monolayer.
